title: VEGOILS-Palm ends lower on worries over import restrictions by India
text:
VEGOILS-Palm ends lower on worries over import restrictions by India

(Adds closing prices, analyst quote)

SINGAPORE, Oct 14 (Reuters) - Malaysian palm oil futures closed lower on Monday as traders fretted about likely import restrictions by top buyer India, and tracking weakness in related edible oils.

The benchmark palm oil contract for December delivery FCPOc3 on the Bursa Malaysia Derivatives Exchange ended 1.3% lower at 2,156 ringgit ($515.05), the lowest since Oct. 4.

Malaysian palm oil futures have been weaker since Friday, after five days of consecutive gains, following news that India is considering restricting imports from Malaysia in reaction to the Malaysian prime minister criticising New Delhi's actions in Kashmir. reported after markets closed on Monday that Indian refiners have stopped buying Malaysian palm oil for shipments in November and December fearing New Delhi could raise import taxes or enforce other measures to curtail imports from Kuala Lumpur. importers would divert their demand to Indonesian origin now in view of India's possible restriction on Malaysian origins," said Anilkumar Bagani, research head of Sunvin Group, a Mumbai-based vegetable oil broker.

Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad said he had not received "anything official" from India. a Kuala Lumpur-based trader also told Reuters that weaker related vegetable oils and a stronger ringgit weighed on the market.

The ringgit, palm oil's currency of trade, was up 0.1%, making the edible oil more expensive for foreign buyers.

U.S. soyoil futures on the Chicago Board of Trade BOc2 were down 0.4%. The January palm oil contract DCPF0 on the Dalian exchange fell 2.5%, while the January soyoil contract DBYF0 declined 0.5%.

Palm oil is affected by price movements in related oils as they compete for a share in the global vegetable oils market.
